pageData.text: During this lab activity, students will observe a wide array of fungi by examining prepared microscope slides. By examining key features of the prepared specimens, students will be able to identify a variety of fungal taxa. After examining prepared slides, students will culture yeast and observe them under a microscope. The yeast will then be stained and examined again, and specimens that are budding will be located and recorded.

Activity 2: Yeast Observations - 60 minutes

pageData.text: Do you know what is the largest organism on Earth? It’s not a whale, but rather the gigantic Armillaria ostoyae. Researchers discovered this fungus while mapping pathogenic fungal species in the Pacific Northwest1.

The huge A. ostoyae fungus was discovered in 1998 in Oregon's Blue Mountains. Researchers estimate that it covers 2,384 acres of soil, or about 1,665 football fields, with a complex underground network. Based on growth rate patterns, it is estimated that the fungus is somewhere between 2,400 to 8,650 years old. Although this species can cause disease in many tree species, fungi in general play a very important role in nutrient cycling and provide many ecosystem services.

1Casselman, A. (2007, October 4). Strange but True: The Largest Organism on Earth Is a Fungus.Scientific American.
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/strange-but-true-largest-organism-is-fungus/

pageData.desc: Armillaria ostoyae fungus growing in a forest.
pageData.altText: Armillaria ostoyae fungus growing in a forest.

pageData.text: A <button class='glossary-text'>fungus</button> (plural, fungi) is a heterotrophic eukaryotic organism that typically absorbs nutrients from the environment, secreting digestive enzymes to break down materials before they are absorbed. Bread mold, yeast, and mushrooms are all examples of fungi. Fungi cells do not contain chlorophyll because unlike plants, fungi are not autotrophs.

While both plants and fungi have cell walls, plants have cell walls made of cellulose, whereas fungi have cell walls made of <button class='glossary-text'>chitin</button>—a polysaccharide that is also found in the shells of arthropods (insects and crustaceans). Current sequencing data indicate that fungi are more closely related to animals than to plants. In addition to the use of chitin, fungi also share other traits with animals, including the use of glycogen as a storage molecule. Additionally, fungi use the same mitochondrial codon variant for the amino acid tryptophan as animals do.

pageData.subTitle: Structure
pageData.text: Most fungi are multicellular. The main body of a multicellular fungus is called the , which is composed of a mass of filamentous structures called (singular, hypha). The structure most commonly associated with fungi, a mushroom, is the reproductive structure of some groups of fungi which is found above the ground, while the main body of the fungus is found underground.

The hyphae can spread out over large distances. For example, in the early 2000s, genetic analysis showed that the hyphae of a single organism (Armillaria ostoyae, commonly called a honey mushroom) extended over 2,200 acres of land.

The cell walls of the hyphae get their strength from chitin. In some species of fungi, , or internal cross-walls, divide the hyphae, creating cell-like structures. The septa have pores, which allow for material, such as cytoplasmic material, organelles, or even nuclei (depending on the size) to flow from one compartment to another. In other species of fungi there are no septa, and the hyphae may contain many hundreds of nuclei. This occurs as a result of mitosis without cytokinesis.While most fungi are multicellular, they may also be unicellular. Unicellular fungi are called yeasts. The term yeast does not refer to a single taxonomic group; different yeasts belong to many different phyla.

pageData.subTitle: Reproduction
pageData.text: Fungi can reproduce either sexually or asexually. Sexual reproduction occurs when two fungi join their mycelia. The nuclei fuse, forming a diploid cell. They then often undergo meiosis, producing haploid spores with a different combination of alleles than that of the parent fungi. Asexual reproduction occurs primarily through the production of spores, which are released from structures called sporangia. Vegetative reproduction, in which a portion of a hypha is broken off and generates a new organism, can also occur. Some unicellular fungi (i.e., yeasts) reproduce asexually by budding, in which a second organism develops from a bud on the original organism. When the two organisms separate, a <button class='glossary-text'>bud scar</button> is formed on the original organism.

pageData.subTitle: Classification
pageData.text: Historically, fungi were classified into four groups based on their reproductive structures: <button class='glossary-text'>Ascomycota</button> (sac fungi), <button class='glossary-text'>Basidiomycota</button> (club fungi), <button class='glossary-text'>Chytridiomycota</button> (chytrids), and <button class='glossary-text'>Zygomycota</button> (bread molds). Recently, sequencing data, which entails defining the order of nucleotides in DNA using genetic coding, has greatly changed the classification of organisms within Kingdom Fungi. Currently, there are seven recognized phyla; however, the classification of fungi continues to change as more genomic data is collected. The following are the currently recognized phyla:

1. was previously considered part of Kingdom Protista; however, sequencing of several genes has found that this phylum may actually be fungi. These organisms are sporeforming and unicellular, and they lack mitochondria. An example of these can be seen in Figure 1, which shows a species of parasitic Microsporidia under a microscope.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Photograph of a species of the sporeforming, parasitic Microsporidia under a microscope.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Photograph of a species of the sporeforming, parasitic Microsporidia under a microscope.

pageData.text: 1. contains organisms that typically live in aquatic or moist habitats. They have motile, flagellated spores. Chytrids can be parasitic or (digesting decayed matter external to the body and absorbing the released nutrients). Batrachochytrium is a parasitic chytrid that has been implicated in the loss of several frog species. Figure 2 shows a frog with skin irritation from a parasitic chytrid .

pageData.desc: Figure 2: A human hand holding a frog that has skin irritation from a parasitic chytrid fungus on its legs and stomach.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A human hand holding a frog that has skin irritation from a parasitic chytrid fungus on its legs and stomach.

pageData.text: 1. was previously considered part of the phylum Chytridiomycota as they have flagellated as spores and gametes (characteristic of phylum Chytridiomycota). However, Blastocladiomycota include fungi that make large networks of mycelia, while Chytridiomycota produces a limited number of mycelia. Organisms in Blastocladiomycota may be saprophytic or parasitic on plants or animals.

1. is a phylum of anaerobic fungi found in the rumens of ungulate animals like cattle. Like Blastocladiomycota, these fungi were once considered part of the Chytridiomycota phylum. Recent research demonstrating that these fungi possess (reduced mitochondria) has placed these fungi into their own phylum.

1. is a phylum of soil fungi that reproduce asexually. These fungi have a mutualistic relationship with plants, forming arbuscular (beneficial associations of fungi and plant roots). These fungi obtain nutrients from the plant and function as an extension of the plant’s root system. They may help the plant obtain necessary nutrients, such as phosphorous, sulfur, nitrogen, and other micronutrients. It has been hypothesized that the presence of these fungi allowed plants to colonize land. They are found in most land plants; some mycologists and botanists estimate that 80% of plants harbor Glomeromycota fungi. Figure 3 shows an example of a mycorrhizae species under a microscope view.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Photograph of an important mycorrhizae species under a microscope which allows plants to obtain nutrients.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Photograph of an important mycorrhizae species under a microscope which allows plants to obtain nutrients.

pageData.text: 1. is a sub-kingdom of fungi, containing two phyla: and . These fungi are sometimes considered “higher fungi,” meaning that they have with well-developed septae. Basidiomycota, often called club fungi, produce . These spores are produced on the , which is a reproductive structure resembling a club. Some mushrooms belong to this group, many of them edible (i.e., white, oyster, shiitake, cremini, and Portobello mushrooms); however, some are toxic and even deadly. Figure 4 shows a picture of the common “puffball” , known as Lycoperdon; most are not poisonous if ingested.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Photograph of Lycoperdon, or the “puffball” fungus, under a microscope. The small round basidiospores can be seen in the image.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Photograph of Lycoperdon, or the “puffball” fungus, under a microscope. The small round basidiospores can be seen in the image.

pageData.question: What tool has greatly changed fungal classification?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Recently, sequencing data, which entails defining the order of nucleotides in DNA using genetic coding, has greatly changed the classification of organisms within Kingdom Fungi.

pageData.question: Which group of fungi lack mitochondria?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Microsporidia are obligate intracellular parasites, sporeforming, unicellular, and they lack mitochondria.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Currently, there are seven recognized phyla; however, the classification of fungi continues to change as more genomic data is collected.  Microsporidia (Figure 1) were previously considered part of Kingdom Protista; however, sequencing of several genes has found that this phylum may actually be fungi. These organisms are obligate intracellular parasites, sporeforming, unicellular, and they lack mitochondria. Blastocladiomycota include fungi that make large networks of mycelia, and they may be saprophytic or parasitic on plants or animals. Neocallimastigomycota is a phylum of anaerobic fungi found in the rumens of ungulate animals like cattle. Glomeromycota is a phylum of soil fungi that reproduce asexually. These fungi have a mutualistic relationship with plants, forming arbuscular mycorrhizae. Dikarya is a sub-kingdom of fungi, containing two phyla: Basidiomycota and Ascomycota. These fungi are sometimes considered “higher fungi,” meaning that they have hyphae with well-developed septae.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Currently, there are seven recognized phyla; however, the classification of fungi continues to change as more genomic data is collected.  Microsporidia (Figure 1) were previously considered part of Kingdom Protista; however, sequencing of several genes has found that this phylum may actually be fungi. These organisms are obligate intracellular parasites, sporeforming, unicellular, and they lack mitochondria. Blastocladiomycota include fungi that make large networks of mycelia, and they may be saprophytic or parasitic on plants or animals. Neocallimastigomycota is a phylum of anaerobic fungi found in the rumens of ungulate animals like cattle. Glomeromycota is a phylum of soil fungi that reproduce asexually. These fungi have a mutualistic relationship with plants, forming arbuscular mycorrhizae. Dikarya is a sub-kingdom of fungi, containing two phyla: Basidiomycota and Ascomycota. These fungi are sometimes considered “higher fungi,” meaning that they have hyphae with well-developed septae.

pageData.text: , often called sac fungi, produce . These spores are produced in the , a reproductive structure that resembles a sac. Phylum Ascomycota is the largest fungal phylum. This group contains many species important to humans, such as the yeast used to ferment beer and wine as well as leaven bread (Saccharomyces), Figure 5, the Penicillium species used to treat bacterial infections, and the edible truffles (Tuber) and morel (Morchella) mushrooms. Figure 6 shows Aspergillus, which is a common genus in the Ascomycota phylum. Figure 7 shows a black truffle (Tuber aestivum).

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Microscopic photograph of a Saccharomyces, the circular species used to ferment beer and wine and leaven bread.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Microscopic photograph of a Saccharomyces, the circular species used to ferment beer and wine and leaven bread.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: A microscopic photograph that shows Aspergillus, which is a common genus in the Ascomycota phylum, and have conidial heads.
pageData.altText: Figure 6: A microscopic photograph that shows Aspergillus, which is a common genus in the Ascomycota phylum, and have conidial heads.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: A black truffle (tuber aestivum) in a person's hand that they have just dug up from the ground. Their hand is over a pile of dirt and leaves with a small hand shovel next to the hand.
pageData.altText: Figure 7: A black truffle (tuber aestivum) in a person's hand that they have just dug up from the ground. Their hand is over a pile of dirt and leaves with a small hand shovel next to the hand.

pageData.text: 1. historically was a phylum within Kingdom Fungi; however, it was found to be paraphyletic and is no longer considered part of Kingdom Fungi. The Zygomycotes are commonly known as bread molds and are mostly terrestrial. Figure 8 shows an example of common “bread mold” or Rhizopus stolonifer.

pageData.desc: Figure 8: A piece of bread that has multiple spots of mold on it; some are green, brown, and purple. This is an example of the common “bread mold” or Rhizopous stolonifer.
pageData.altText: Figure 8: A piece of bread that has multiple spots of mold on it; some are green, brown, and purple. This is an example of the common “bread mold” or Rhizopous stolonifer.

pageData.text: They create zygospores (specialized thick-walled spores) during sexual reproduction. Many of the former Zygomycotes have been placed into sub-phyla that do not fall under any particular phylum. There are four recognized sub-phyla: Kickxellomycotina, Zoopagomycotina, Entomophthoromycotina, and Mucoromycotina.

pageData.question: Which group of fungi are often called sac fungi?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Ascomycota are often called sac fungi and produce ascospores. These spores are produced in the ascus, a reproductive structure that resembles a sac.

pageData.question: Which fungi form symbiotic relationships with plants?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: It has been hypothesized that the presence of Glomeromycotes allowed plants to colonize terrestrial environments.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Glomeromycota is a phylum of soil fungi that reproduce asexually. These fungi have a mutualistic relationship with plants, forming arbuscular mycorrhizae (beneficial associations of fungi and plant roots). These fungi obtain nutrients from the plant and function as an extension of the plant’s root system. They may help the plant obtain necessary nutrients, such as phosphorus, sulfur, nitrogen, and other micronutrients. Basidiomycota, often called club fungi, produce basidiospores. These spores are produced on the basidium, which is a reproductive structure resembling a club. Some mushrooms belong to this group, many of them edible (i.e., white, oyster, shiitake, cremini, and Portobello mushrooms); however, some are toxic and even deadly. Phylum Ascomycota is the largest fungal phylum. This group contains many species important to humans, such as the yeast used ferment beer and wine, and leaven bread (Saccharomyces); the Penicillium species used to treat bacterial infections; and edible mushrooms like truffles (Tuber) and morels (Morchella). Although no longer considered part of Kingdom Fungi, Zygomycotes are commonly known as bread molds and are mostly terrestrial.

Some mushrooms belong to this group, many of them edible (i.e., white, oyster, shiitake, cremini, and Portobello mushrooms); however, some are toxic and even deadly. Phylum Ascomycota is the largest fungal phylum. This group contains many species important to humans, such as the yeast used ferment beer and wine, and leaven bread (Saccharomyces); the Penicillium species used to treat bacterial infections; and edible mushrooms like truffles (Tuber) and morels (Morchella). pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, place a prepared slide on the microscope. Then, observe and sketch the organism on the slide. Next, classify the organism. This activity is repeated until 6 slides are observed. In Activity 2, create a yeast mixture, then create a wet mount of the yeast mixture. Next, observe the slide. Then, create a second slide with stained yeast and observe the slide.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.
Methylene blue may be harmful if swallowed. It can also stain clothes, skin, and surfaces so use caution and carry out the staining procedure on top of paper towels to prevent this.

pageData.desc: corrosion symbol
pageData.altText: corrosion symbol
pageData.text: Chlorine bleach is a corrosive material. Use this near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eye wash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes. Do not use bleach in an area without proper ventilation, such as an open window or a bathroom with a fan

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which term is used for the main body of a multicellular fungus?
Which of the following phyla includes fungi that are directly beneficial to humans?
Which of the following phyla includes anaerobic fungi found in the rumens of animals like cattle?
Why are the members of sub-kingdom Dikarya considered “higher fungi”?

options.text: They have hyphae with well-developed septae.
They grow on tree limbs rather than in soil.
They are well-known for causing death of several frog species.
They are used by humans to produce beer and wine.

assestmentData.question: A new fungus species is discovered; it secretes digestive enzymes into the environment and absorbs the resulting nutrients. Based on this information, which of the following terms best describes this fungus?
Which phylum consists of organisms that create specialized thick-walled spores during sexual reproduction?
Which of the following molecules is found in fungal cell walls and not plant cell walls?
Which of the following items will you need to supply yourself to complete this investigation?
What is the proper ratio of chlorine bleach to water to create surface disinfectant for this investigation?
Which of the following is a safety hazard associated with methylene blue?

options.text: It can stain clothing, skin and surfaces.

Read through the Activities.
Obtain all materials. You may want to print this drawing template to organize your sketches in this investigation.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
In Activity 1, you will observe and sketch prepared slides of fungi to classify each organism.

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Examine the slides using a microscope. Draw each structure and determine the phylum each specimen belongs to. Record your phylum data in Data Table 1. Photograph your labeled drawings. Include 2-3 drawings in each photo if you are not using the drawing template. For the purpose of this activity, consider a phylum of fungi.
Microscope Tip: Focus initially using a lower powered lens and then switch to higher magnification to examine details and/or smaller organisms.

tableData.text: Fungal hyphae inside of orchid roots
An ascus (a sac-like structure) containing ascospores
Sporangia, a round structure containing spores and zygospores
Sporangia, a round structure containing spores

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will prepare unstained and stained wet mounts of a yeast mixture to observe budding yeast.
Place ½ teaspoon of yeast and ½ teaspoon of sugar (sucrose) in the 250-mL beaker.
Add 100 mL of warm tap water (35–40 °C) to the beaker. Mix thoroughly by stirring with a plastic spoon.
Note: Temperatures above 40 °C will kill the yeast.

pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Allow the beaker to sit for 30 minutes.
Use a pipet to collect a small sample of the yeast mixture.
Place a small drop of the yeast mixture onto a microscope slide.
Hold a coverslip above the drop and rest one edge of the coverslip on the slide at a 45-degree angle (without touching the drop).
Slowly lower the coverslip until it covers the drop.
Observe the yeast using your microscope. Look for budding yeasts. Record your findings in Data Table 2.
Remove the slide from the microscope and set it aside.
Use a pipet to collect another small sample of the yeast mixture.
Place a small drop on a clean microscope slide.
Use the end of the pipet to spread the drop out across the slide.
Allow the slide to dry.
Light the tea candle.
Attach the clothespin to the end of the slide. The clothespin will allow you to safely hold the slide while heating it, as the glass will get hot.
Using the clothespin, hold the slide over the candle with the yeast sample facing upwards away from the flame.
Move the slide over the flame so that the flame touches the entire slide. Repeat this three times.

pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Hold the slide in the air, allowing it to cool. This should take approximately two minutes.
Place the slide on the tray.
Drop the stain (methylene blue) on the sample until it is completely covered in stain.

pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Wait 1 minute.
Hold the clothespin and tilt the slide at a 45-degree angle.

Gently rinse the stain off the slide with distilled water. Do not pour water directly on the sample, instead pour the water on the slide above the sample and allow the water to run down the slide over the sample. Repeat until the water runs clear.
Fold a sheet of bibulous paper in half. Place the slide between the two halves of the paper and gently press down to dry the slide.
Remove the slide from between the two pieces of paper and wipe the back of the slide (the side with no sample) to remove the soot that accumulated on the back during the heating process.
Remove the clothespin from the slide.
Observe the yeast using your microscope. Look for budding yeasts. Record your findings in Data Table 2.

Caution: Wear appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) when working with bleach: gloves, lab apron, and chemical splash goggles. Ensure adequate ventilation when using bleach; if possible, open a window.

text: Glass slides and coverslips should be disposed of as though they are broken glass —wrap the glass slides and coverslips in newspapers, paper bags, or other sturdy paper, tape the paper securely shut, and place it in the trash. This prevents anyone who handles the trash from cutting themselves should the glass break. These materials can also be put into a container, such as a small cardboard box, that can be sealed and disposed of in the trash.
Pour a 10% bleach solution (1 part bleach to 9 parts water) into your yeast solution.

pageData.desc: Making Surface Disinfectant

pageData.text: Cover the container and allow it to remain undisturbed for 24 hours. After 24 hours, dispose of any solid material in the trash and any liquids in the sink.

text: Wash and dry the beaker and graduated cylinder. Put both back into the equipment kit.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.desc: completion
pageData.altText: completion

pageData.text: For the purposes of this activity, consider Zygomycota a phylum.

tableData.text: This fungus has hyphae inside the roots of plants, such as orchids.
The apothecium is the cup-shaped fruiting body of the fungus.  These fungi produce asci, sac-like structures that contain ascospores.
Many Coprinus mushrooms are referred to as inky caps due to the black substance they release with their spores. These organisms have basidia, club-shaped structures that contain basidiospores.
Rhizopus is commonly known as black bread mold. It produces sporangia, which produce specialized zygospores.
One of the few genera of chytrids to have a true alternation of generations. Allomyces sporophytes produce flagellated zoospores.
Lichen is an organism composed of both algae and fungi.  The algae live symbiotically inside the hyphae of the fungus.

pageData.text: Insert the photos of your drawings of the fungi viewed on each prepared slide: endotrophic mycorrhiza, cap fungus apothecium, Coprinus mushroom sporangia, Rhizopus combination, Allomyces sporophyte, and lichen ascocarps. If you did not use the drawing template, include multiple drawings in each photo and clearly label each drawing with the organism’s name.  You may upload a maximum of 3 photos for this activity.

pageData.title: Questions
text: How did the stained yeast and the unstained yeast differ?

When yeasts are alive, methylene blue cannot stain the yeast cells because enzymes in the yeast react with the methylene blue and render it colorless.  Explain how brewers, who use yeast to ferment beverages, could use methylene blue to their advantage.

data.title: Ascomycota
data.content: The largest phylum of Kingdom Fungi; its members produce ascospores and are also known as sac fungi

data.title: Ascospore
data.content: A sexual spore found in an ascus (sac) in certain fungus species

data.title: Ascus
data.content: A reproductive structure that resembles a sac

data.title: Basidiomycota
data.content: A phylum of Kingdom Fungi whose members produce basidiospores; members include many edible and poisonous mushrooms,  shelf fungi, rusts, and smuts

data.title: Basidiospore
data.content: A reproductive spore produced by Basidiomycete fungi

data.title: Basidium
data.content: A reproductive structure resembling a club

data.title: Blastocladiomycota
data.content: Contains fungi that make large networks of mycelia, have flagellated as spores and gametes

data.title: Bud scar
data.content: A crater-like ring of chitinous scar tissue located on the surface of the mother cell

data.title: Chitin
data.content: A polysaccharide found in the cell walls of fungi and the shells of arthropods

data.title: Chytridiomycota
data.content: A phylum of Kingdom Fungi whose members typically live in aquatic or moist habitats, have motile flagellated spores, and are either parasitic or saprophytic; members are informally known as chytrids

data.title: Dikarya
data.content: A sub-kingdom of fungi, containing two phyla: Basidiomycota and Ascomycota, have hyphae with well-developed septae, “higher fungi”

data.title: Fungus
data.content: A heterotrophic eukaryotic organism that typically absorbs nutrients from the environment, secreting digestive enzymes to break down materials before they are absorbed; plural, fungi

data.title: Glomeromycota
data.content: A phylum of Kingdom Fungi whose members are soil fungi that reproduce asexually

data.title: Hydrogenosome
data.content: A membrane-enclosed organelle found in some anaerobic ciliates, flagellates, and fungi

data.title: Hyphae
data.content: Long, branching, filamentous structures of a fungus, oomycete, or actinobacterium; singular, hypha

data.title: Microsporidia
data.content: A phylum of Kingdom Fungi that includes obligate intracellular parasites that are spore-forming, unicellular, and lack mitochondria

data.title: Mycelium
data.content: The vegetative part of a fungus, consisting of a network of fine white filaments (hyphae); plural, mycelia

data.title: Mycorrhizae
data.content: Beneficial associations of fungi and plant roots

data.title: Neocallimastigomycota
data.content: A phylum of anaerobic fungi found in the rumens of ungulate animals like cattle

data.title: Saprophytic
data.content: Describes an organism that obtains nutrients by digesting decayed matter external to the body and absorbing the released nutrients

data.title: Septa
data.content: An internal cross-wall that divides the hyphae but still allows material to flow from one compartment to another

data.title: Zygomycota
data.content: A former phylum of Kingdom Fungi whose members are now classified under four recognized subphyla; its members are mostly terrestrial and commonly known as bread molds
